reviews.advice: Actually think about your employees and try to find out why there's such a high turnover rate and how that correlates with individual centres' performance
reviews.cons:
Senior level management regards you as just a number, there is a total lack of regard for employees' wellbeing at EF. The regional management find that avoiding issues is their primary means of solving them -- and they do not keep any of their promises. In particular, you're often misled by EF's job postings and advertisements -- you're led to believe that you'll have plenty of time to travel around China but in reality, you're working on weekdays from 2 to 8:30 pm and 9 hours on Saturday and Sunday, sometimes working for one week consecutively with no break. At Kids and Teens Own Schools, it's up to the individual centres' DoS discretion and they will make sure to overwork you and squeeze every single pulp out of you. They possess full control over each teacher, and if they don't like you, they will try to make things as difficult as they can for you and think of every single reason to get rid of you,  and justify their actions for doing so. The DoS at my centre was nitpicky about everything and it was clear that she placed reducing the centre's costs over their own teachers' welfare. Now it's quite clear why some centres, especially in the Pudong district, are facing high turnover rates -- the DoS tries to cut down on the number of teachers, which in turn creates even more workload for the remaining teachers left, and causes a vicious loop.
Teachers were sick, exhausted and overworked at my centre -- there's usually no time for dinner in between classes. Because of the conditions, work hours and lack of proper treatment, most teachers quit or do not have their contracts renewed at the end of the first year -- and individual centre managers think that it's not worth spending their precious time training new teachers when you're about to leave anyway. When you're hired, you feel like you're given support/your questions get answered and once you're actually at your centre, you're on your own. EF's core values states quality, passion and integrity, but the real situation is quite different and teachers are often placed at the bottom of the chain.

I'd advise anyone who is considering coming to re-consider their motives and think hard about coming here. It's clear that there are cracks in the company's system, if there are so many teachers leaving and new teachers coming in to replace them every 2 weeks.

reviews.advice: Pay local staff better and don’t make teachers face retribution when they leave your center for something much better.
reviews.cons:
From worst to least worst:

* EF Management will not keep their word. I worked there for 10 months then put in my two months notice and even have screenshots of my DoS saying my work visa would be transferred to my new school. EF waited until my last week to tell me they, and the investors, were refusing to transfer my work visa and I’d have to return to the USA in a few days or I’d be in the country illegally and face jail time. I am now in the US. 

* EF will go behind your back and cancel your permits without your consent or knowledge but inform you last minute.

* You aren’t actually trained but are instructed to observe a fellow teacher and after a week begin co- teaching  then receive the classes from the teacher who left before you. I went without a Senior Teacher observing me ever for 8 months and received no feedback. 
 

* The schedule for the following week will be made Sunday evening or even Monday of that week. 

* Newest teachers will be assigned Marketing Events due to their free schedule. Marketing at EF Jiaxing was a nightmare where I would speak to someone a week prior about an event I was assigned to only to be told nothing was needed of me except my attendance and participation. Come the day of the marketing team member would frantically ask me to prepare something like a report to read students or flash cards for a recent holiday then tell me the event isn’t 30 minutes as on my schedule but two hours. Also it isn’t in the center anymore it’s at a library on a stage. 

* The weekly workshops at EF Jiaxing contain no development or educational value. They are workshops for 3 hours that contain menial tasks corporate didn’t want to bother with and handed them down the ladder.

reviews.advice: Pay your employees a fair wage; hire management that won’t muck everything up so much!
reviews.cons:
Where to start? I’ve lived all over the world and worked in a myriad of work environments- I’m not adverse to hard work, but everything about EF is ‘predatory’. 

They actively recruit students right out of university that have little to no idea about what they want to do in the future. They promise them relatively decent pay vis-a-vis the current living cost. They additionally swear ‘up and down’ that new recruits will positively ‘love’ China and that they’ll be supported! 

The reality is starkly different. I found myself in China after my BA for no other reason than I wanted to learn Mandarin- I already speak several other languages and thought this would round me out. I began teaching classes after just one week of observation, which should’ve been the first red flag. As we were so short staffed due the ever-growing number of people that did ‘midnight runners’ because of the poor work environment, I easily worked 50 hour weeks from the start. This was later compounded by mandatory summer and winter schools that added another 12 hours and reduced my time off to just one, singular, solitary day. Were we compensated for the extra time in the class room? Hardly- we were given just 600 kuai per ‘camp’, which translates to just €80  or $85 at the time of writing. If you think that €6 to $7 per hour sounds bad for a college graduate, JUST WAIT! 

The regular salary is abysmal- positively abysmal. I’ve been paid better for internships. For a 50 hour work week I was paid just €1.190 or $1,290 per month. Which, again, averages out to an almost WHOPPING €6 or $6.50 an hour. If that wasn’t horrific enough, any halfway decent apartment costs at LEAST €400. And that living stipend they promised you? That covers maybe half, if you’re lucky. You aren’t able to save, in fact, you just barely scrap by. 

Which brings me to my next point. If you want to break your contract for any reason, you have to pay them- 30,000 kuai (€4.000) to be exact. Given the cost of living and the salary they pay you, you could maybe, MAYBE, afford to do that after 10 months if you’re prudent with your money, but even then that’s incredibly difficult. They’ve got you exactly where they want you. 

But why would you want to leave? If being paid a slave’s wages wasn’t discouragement enough, perhaps the work culture might be? Whilst working 50 hour weeks and consistently covering for other colleagues that had left or taken ill from the stress that came with the job, I was asked to repeatedly stay longer to decorate classrooms and just generally put in more time that was necessary. If you called in sick (because frankly, working with kid’s really tests your immune system) you had to qualify your sickness with the DOS. I had horrific gynecological issues whilst in China and despite my embarrassment, had to brief the management team when I asked to take a day off. I was once only allowed to leave my post after being sick in a trash bin. 

But, that’s only the metaphorical ‘tip of the iceberg’. Whilst working for EF I experienced sexual harassment, threat of violence and, to a less important degree, workplace misconduct. I had a colleague yell harassment at me at a work event, telling another colleague that I was a ‘whore’ and a ‘slut’, despite the fact that we were only talking about 90s pop. This continued into the workplace, when he frequently made comments of a sexual nature to me. My DOS, Carmel’s, response was that I shouldn’t be so provocative, despite the fact that I was wearing the company issues navy blue polo and ankle length khakis. Who would’ve thought that golf is the sexiest sport? 

A few months later, a 13 year old came to my class with a switchblade. He threatened another student that often made jokes at his expense. I stepped in between the two boys and managed to wrestle the knife away. I went to my manager directly and said I would no longer teach the child as I didn’t feel safe and didn’t want to feel unsafe in my work environment. Her response was to send a note home with the offending teenager, which was obviously ineffective. He remained in my class until I left my post. 

Lastly, my DOS was sleeping with a Senior Teacher, who was arguably promoted because of his personal relationship, not because of seniority. She would regularly come to our office and sit in his lap or just generally throw herself at him. 

When I tendered my letter of resignation to my DOS’s boss, I received an exit interview. Who should be in this interview, but my poorly behaved DOS? She proceeded to effectively try to ‘rip me a new one’ mid-interview. It had the opposite effect, I believe. 

TLDR; Don’t work for EF, you will regret it.

reviews.advice: Way too much to type. Start paying your employees competitive salaries that they deserve instead of trickling it across time, stop trying to just keep people- theyll want to leave even more, its like a hostage situation with travel and other documents being kept. Center managers/PMs, etc, recruiters, NEED to be trained on how to actually hear their employees and support whats best for them and then need to be held accountable/have honest employee feedback.  Tell employees what they are getting into from the BEGINNING of recruitment what they are getting into with expenses, etc.
reviews.cons:
DONT take their loan if you can avoid it- its a trap to make you stay with them. Very low pay! You can get paid 3X their pay at private international schools.  Will try to rip you off with starting pay, but thankfully China has a decent band system according to relevant degree and experience. You can get fired without being “fired” during your first couple months of probation bc you aren’t technically an employee yet. 
Manipulative center management that will try to keep you there at all costs! They get an incentive for you to stay, and to resign on. Trying to communicate with them is tricky at best- like a sound board; condescending, prejudiced, and racist at worst.  Co workers, especially PAs, will throw you under the bus at any given opportunity. 
Theyll try to lie about your passport being somewhere else, and theyll hide it at Headquarters so you cant leave- report to embassy if this happens. Adults is much better to work with if you can get into it, but its being phased out. Kids and teens at most centers is a nightmare. 
The certifications and promotions are gate kept at all costs so you can stay longer to get them. Dont expect your recruiter to support you once you’re there- they also get incentive to keep you there and really dont care about YOUR best interests. Teacher engagement hype on social media and recruitment is a joke, would you want to spend more time with people like the above^^? Some people will have their flight tickets paid and others wont- even in the same group of onboarding staff/city- really unfair.

reviews.advice: Respect your employees. We are all qualified, educated adults who deserve to be treated with dignity and respect. End the shaming culture, pay your employees what they deserve, treat ALL local staff (including TAs, CCs and PAs) like the foreign staff. End discriminatory hiring practices. Tell people about the Summer Course 60 hour work week upfront or don't do it at all. Report possible instances of child abuse, I saw a grown man kick his child in the middle of the school and nothing was done, it's certainly not my place as a foreigner who can't report child abuse, it is management's place. Don't value the money over your employees and students. Use the actual latest and most promising resesrch in teaching. Accommodate children and employees with disabilities. Be better. Remember that just because it's legal doesnt mean its right.
reviews.cons: 60 hour work week with 1 day off they will not tell you about until you've already signed the contract, long hours, pays much less than industry standard, no sick leave and few vacation days, pays and treats local staff even worse, will not report potential child abuse for fear of losing a customer, will put a child in a class that is far too difficult for money, currently desperately understaffed because they can't get anyone new in and anyone already in the country knows EF's reputation and is avoiding it, even in non-pandemic times you will be overworked and disrespected. Management at least at my location was inexperienced, cruel, belittling, disrespectful, and absolutely willing and able to yell at staff until they cried. If management makes a mistake ( even minor ones), teachers will pay for it and be blamed and have it held against them and used against them. If you want to quit you have to pay an exorbitant fee (in USD) to buy out your contract or hand in a 3 month notice, if you do hand in your notice you will be abused and harasses by management until your flight leaves, even in the months before your contract is up you will have multiple hours-long meetings about signing on for another contract (like a coerced confession). The students are pushed to breaking points by parents and the school doesn't help, why are we giving a 4 year old an exam? The "stars" system from the 80s or 90s that rewards children for good behavior in class and punishes them for bad behavior by adding and taking away stars is mandatory despite being unhealthy and out of date. Neurodivergent children and children with physical disabilities are left behind unless their teacher is aware of ways to help or is neurodivergent or disabled themselves. No training or direction on how to teach children with these disabilities, as an autistic person I tried to make my classes as accessible as possible and despite being the newest teacher, became the Go To in the office for disabled children, with no support, acknowledgment, or backing from management. Chinese culture is very much about saving face and this clearly western company uses that against all staff, especially local staff in public shaming of minor mistakes (not pulling up the blinds in the classroom, etc), treats local staff absolutely abysmally- 60-70 hour work week with 2 day off for them always, 5-8000 CNY per month, fewer vacation days, more responsibilities, all while called and treated as a teacher's assistant by management. Depending on the city you go to and who hired you, will only hire white people, especially blonde and attractive white people, some cities will hire black and brown people, probably nowhere will hire people of Chinese or Asian descent as foreign teachers. Management, at least at my location, has a deep disrespect of Chinese culture. One of the only requirements for being management is not leaving after 1 or 2 contracts, so there's upward mobility I guess? But that also means that the people who are okay with being treated this way are now in charge of everyone and often will continue the cycle. The school I am in will lose 4/7 foreign teachers in the next 6 months with no sign of being able to get more, 6/10 of the local teachers are planning on leaving as soon as they can, and they are still finding a way to blame it on the employees. A management seminar in Shanghai said people leave because of "no loyalty" and "culture shock". We have had so many employees stay for 2 weeks before leaving, and even more desperately want to leave but can't because of financial, contractual, or other reasons. Unless this company changes it's going to collapse and crush everyone in it, especially teachers and students.
